questiontext.text:
Exercise

The symmetric matrix \[A={@a@}\] has eigenvalues \({@double_eigval@},{@double_eigval@},{@single_eigval@}\) (i.e. eigenvalue \({@double_eigval@}\) is repeated with multiplicity \(2\)).

Associated with the non-repeated eigenvalue \({@single_eigval@}\) is an eigenvector \[X={@covect1(single_eigvec)@}\] (or any non-zero multiple).

  1. Normalize the eigenvector \(X\): [[input:ans_xunit]] [[validation:ans_xunit]]
    [[feedback:prt_xunit]]

  2. Investigate the eigenvectors associated with the repeated eigenvalue \({@double_eigval@}\): find a general form of these eigenvectors:

    [[input:ans_dvecs]] [[validation:ans_dvecs]]
    [[feedback:prt_dvecs]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. Normalizing \(X\) which has magnitude \(\sqrt{({@single_eigvec[1]@})^2+({@single_eigvec[2]@})^2+({@single_eigvec[3]@})^2} = {@norm(single_eigvec)@}\) gives \[\frac{1}{{@norm(single_eigvec)@}}{@covect1(single_eigvec)@} = {@single_normalized@}.\]

  2. The eigenvectors associated with \(\lambda={@double_eigval@}\) satisfy \(AY={@double_eigval@}Y\) which gives \[{@a-double_eigval*ident(3)@}{@covect1([x,y,z])@} = {@zeromatrix(3,1)@}.\] All three equations simplify to \({@eq@}\). Having a single equation with three unknowns, we choose two of the variables to be parameters \({@uu@},{@vv@}\) and thus obtain that \[Y={@covect1(gensol)@}\] where \({@uu@},{@vv@}\) are arbitrary (but not both simultaneously zero).

Further discussion

A certain amount of care is now require in the choice of \({@uu@}\) and \({@vv@}\) if we are to find an orthogonal modal matrix to diagonalize \(A\).

For any choice \[X^TY = {@matrix(single_eigvec)@}{@covect1(gensol)@} = {@(simp:false,xy_comp)@} = {@(simp:true,zeromatrix(1,1))@},\] so \(X\) and \(Y\) are orthogonal. (The normalization of \(X\) does not affect this.)

However, we also need two orthogonal eigenvectors of the form \({@covect1(gensol)@}\). One possibility to calculate them is as follows. Obtain one vector by choosing both parameters, for example \({@uu@}=0\), \({@vv@}=1\) which yields \(Y^{(1)}={@covect1(vecs[2])@}\). To calculate the second vector, we consider the equation expressing orthogonality, that is, \(Y^TY^{(1)}={@zeromatrix(1,1)@}\), which simplifies to \({@yy1_comp@}=0\). Choosing \({@uu@}=1\), we calculate \({@vv@}\), which leads to the vector \(Y^{(2)}={@covect1(vecs[1])@}\).

After normalization, these become \(Y^{(1)}={@covect1(vecs_norm[2])@}\) and \(Y^{(2)}={@covect1(vecs_norm[1])@}\). Hence the matrix \[P = \left[\begin{matrix}X&\vdots&Y^{(1)}&\vdots &Y^{(2)}\end{matrix}\right] = {@modalmat@}\] is orthogonal and diagonalizes \(A\): \[P^TAP = {@diag_matrix(single_eigval,double_eigval,double_eigval)@}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
The general form of eigenvectors is always a linear expression, i.e. each coordinate is a sum of terms, each of which is a number multiplied by a parameter. There are no powers of parameters, or multiplication between the parameters themselves.

The expression(s) you entered are not linear.
Your expression does not generate all the eigenvectors for \(\lambda={@double_eigval@}\).
Your expression includes vectors which are not eigenvectors for \(\lambda={@double_eigvec@}\) (other than the zero vector).
Your vector has magnitude \({@ans_xunit_norm@}\neq 1\), so it is not a unit vector.
Your vector is not a multiple of the vector \(X\).
Your answer, the zero vector, is never an eigenvector (by definition).
